description.text: attention! I tested this only with nerf jolt out! It can penetrate a carton box side. Never shoot at people with it, because it is very dangerous.

This is a derivative of the apparently impossible cube puzzle.  While a Cube is cool a sphere is much cooler.  I take no credit for the original design from which this was derived.
I didn't have to original model used so I grabbed the impossible cube STLs and unioned them with a sphere (as appropriate).

Print two "s1" parts and two "s2" parts on your well calibrated 3d printer. (I printed in .3 height 10% infill on my ToM) You may need to clean up any little blobs. This solves the same way as the cube it's a little harder due to not being able to set it on a flat surface. I recommend scaling this up a little bit after printing it myself. Unless you have tiny hands it's challenge to put together at the size posted. Check ou derivative: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:25395 - Open Scad Source (works w/ cube and sphere). It fits together a little tighter and as a result is a little more fiddly to put together. If your printer isn't well calibrated print mine LOL.

comments.text: The dimensions might be slightly off - I eyeballed it in Opescad with the STL files you posted up.  I don't have a program that does dimensioning installed so I lined them up the best I could and unioned them with a sphere.  It could be my dimensions were off slightly resulting in the less than perfect fit.  Mine came out pretty good - but it's small and did require a little clean-up with sandpaper on a couple of the faces.  I like your write-up!  Keep up the good work.  My ToM is down right now.  About 6 mos ago I dropped my HBP and snapped off the connector...and did a less than optimal repair.  It finally broke loose again resulting in almost melting the connector when it shorted.  Fortunately I have a spare HBP - I just need to mount it and get it leveled out...unfortunately it's slightly warped and causing me some issues.

title: Nerf Mod MKII Trigger - reduced play & magnet return

description.text:
I decided to try to design a trigger that had less play in the rear.

I got the idea from TacticalCAD as he had a trigger for the recon, but I couldn't import it correctly into my program to change the from and check distance from the catch.

So I had to re-design one from scratch. Then I thought...I have rare earth magnets...boom, "magnet return."

I know, the stupid names are probably better flipped, but I'm lazy...I'm not even sure why I'm typing all of this....shoot, i'm typing this at work...true story.

Anyways. You'll need two rare earth magnets. Go ahead and try to mod the files to suit the magnet you can get, but mine was round ones measured at 6.4 mm in diameter and 1.65 mm in height.

The "anchor" magnet fits right into the MKII slot were the stock spring used to sit and it lines up perfectly with the trigger portion.

I printed the Trigger upside down with supports as the bottom of the long piece and the top part of the "fin" part on the trigger are the only parts that ride on something.

Also, the "U" shaped portion on the front can catch the inner portion of the body, so you can sand and round it down later.

For future updates, I will re-mod the sear release a little more as this current design only reduces the slack by about 60% of travel. I'll make it longer to get it as perfect as I can.

Plus I'll put up a file to fill in the "U" part of the trigger for those of you that just ripped out the "trigger lock" anyways. I void warranties too.
:
*****UPDATED****

I have three files for you now.

I have extended them all an extra 2 mm so they should just touch the rear sear mechanism.

  1. Extended Trigger with OEM design
  2. Extended Trigger minus the trigger lock notch
  3. Extended Trigger with magnet mod and minus the trigger lock notch.

I have uploaded all STL and Sketchup files.

A bust to showcase jewelry.
Added an ear ring holder

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm or variable height

Infill:

none

Notes:

This is printed in vase/spiral mode.
The shoulders are very flat, so a high resolution is needed there. You can print everything in 0.1mm, which takes a long time. Or use Slic3r PE variable layer height feature. Use 0.2mm and set the shoulders to be at 0.1 (green) and the steep parts to be 0.3mm (red).
I used a 0.5 mm nozzle and and flow of 150%.(extr factor 1.5)
The bottom should be at least .9mm to make it heavy enough, else it might tip backwards. The bottom layers are printer at a 100% (extr factor 1)

print_settings.Notes:: I used 0.35mm FAST settings in Slic3r Prusa Edition and typical 1.75 PLA settings (Hotend temp 210c, Bed temp 56c)

title: Printrbot Jr. V2 Stylized extruder pieces (more to come)

description.text:
Waring: I haven't actually printed out these things yet to see if they all do what they are suppose to do. If you find a problem before I fix it, tell me UPDATE (4/1/14) uploaded the correct left plate (hole for motor needed to be deeper) & modified tension latch
UPDATE: added another internal plate to match the style
UPDATE: previous left side plate didn't fit with motor correctly, fixed it, fixed cross-cut things
UPDATE: flattened the bottom of the latch and increased hole size based off the style in my 60mm printrbot jr side fan mount, I've made these plates and a latch to complement the design. more to come... maybe my fan mount design:
60mm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:246204
40mm: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:248367 note that the latch doesn't have a fan attached on purpose

comments.text: Question... for anyone out there who might know: these pieces I'm making for the printrbot Jr. v2 extruder... is this any infringement of copyright/patents? Im taking their publicly released sketches for the printrbot simple direct drive extruder and modifying them to fit the jr. (as well as aesthetic changes). If anyone knows if I may or may not be bordering on someone elses design rights please tell me and I will act accordingly.
comments.author: omniverse

comments.text: The rules for their released designs are that you may use them, modify them, or share them, but you cannot sell them. If you printed 50 of them and put them up on ebay they would have right to take legal action. Same goes for all their released designs. You must have explicit permission to sell derivative works, but not to change them and share them.
comments.author: omniverse

comments.text: you may want to think about how the latch is printed... i realize now that my cuts in what was suppose to be the flat bottom might make it hard to print without support. if anyone wants me to remove those i can upload another version
comments.author: omniverse

comments.text:
I drew up a one piece extruder head (instead of 5 pieces stacked) I had a weak spot so I think I will use your side plates and latch and remove them from my center piece. If it all works out I will post it and link to this and the fan plates. \
Thanks for sharing
comments.author: omniverse

comments.text: Wow awesome, fyi i had gotten to upload the fixed left plate until now, it will still work but it wouldn't be snug with the motor because i hadn't made the cut deep enough. the correct one should be there now.

author: Vr6turbo

title: AnyCubic i3 Mega Hotend Fan Holder

description.text:
This is a replacement for the metal fan guard that comes shippped with the printer and I used the included PLA to print this replacement. This removes some of the restrictive airflow and whistle that the stock guard creates, while holding the fan in about the same location as the stock hardware.

In replacing the stock hardware, you need to replace the part fan holder, and the hotend fan holder as the original metal holder is a single piece of bent metal.

Fan Holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2538250

You will need some Metric M2 nuts to be properly secured. I tried a "No Nut" version, and though it held tight, it felt less secure than this does. The Rear bolt needs to be M2x6mm to not interfere with the fan, but the others can be 6mm or longer. I will also upload the brace as soon as I make final corrections to the models.

Printer:

AnyCubic i3 Mega

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.4 mm

Infill:

40%
AnyCubic i3 Mega Hotend Fan holder printed with the included PLA
An earlier version I did with Shapr3D on my iPad.

title: Laser mount for the much4 assembly

description.text:
A combination of the original mount for a laser and two guidance lasers and a x carriage from openbuilds ( http://openbuilds.org/builds/much4-laserv-printed-version.937/ )

Have not printed it yet, and it could be the mini V wheels in front miss a few mm space to rotate freely ( I wanted the laser module as close to the x axis as possible). Filing some material away could be needed.

Update 170817: wheels have clearance, no need to file anything away. Discovered the space to mount the laser module was larger then my module(3.1 x 3.1 cm), so I took the holders for the guidance lasers and put them onto my other carriage ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2426652 )

[3D print] 00127
[BUY] GoPro HERO4 Session lens replacement kit
[BUY] 4x 2,2x10 self-tapping screws (or similar)
http://www.tme.eu/pl/details/b2.2x10_bn13577/wkrety/bossard/2000091/
[BUY] 8x 1,4x4 self-tapping screws (or longer) (http://www.tme.eu/pl/details/b14x4_bn13577/wkrety/bossard/3351564/)
[BUY] 4x 2x5 self-tapping screws
[BUY] Silicone sealant
[BUY] Rubber bushing that fits 12,5 mm dia. holes for camera cables (best all rubber, but can use: http://www.tme.eu/pl/details/ag-12gy1/dlawnice/kss-wiring/)
[BUY] Plastidip

Fits: https://shop.turtlerover.com/products/fisheye-usb-single-board-camera

To make sure the 3D printed parts are watertight (most prints aren't), spray them with Plastidip before assembly.
GoPro replacement kit comes already with screws, but as they are not supposed to be used in plastics, we need to replace them with self tapping 1.4x4. Remember to fit rubber o-ring between the lens and 00127.
Fit rubber bushing inside the large hole in 00128 and push camera cables through the bushing. Cut the camera board outer sides to fit the case . Assemble the camera to 00128 using 2x5 screws.
The upper and lower case are connected together using 4x 2,2x9,5 tap screws with silicone sealant between sides.

If everything assembled right, it should fit well and remain watertight.

See more on:
www.turtlerover.com
www.facebook.com/TurtleRover

description.text:
This is a plastic arm for a traditional toilet cistern. It connects the handle bar to the plunger inside the cistern. Mine broke so I decided to 3D print a replacement.

It includes a recess and hole for a 3mm bolt. This prevents the arm sliding along the handle bar.

Distance between the holes : 55mm
Square hole : 8mm
Circular hole : 5mm diameter
Bolt hole : 4mm diameter
Overall height : 15mm/20mm
Overall width : 20mm/28mm

I'm not sure how universal toilet cistern arms are so this may not suit all systems. Note that the square hole is rotated slightly in relation to the main body.

title: Motor pinion for ALPS DPG1301 mini plotter (used in Sharp CE-150 and others)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I recently received a Sharp PC-1500 pocket computer with CE-150 printer. Besides the leaky 35-year old NiCd that I replaced the printer gave me the dreaded CHECK:6 error, which was traced to stuck mechanics due to cracked motor pinions.

I didn't expect this to work given the tiny size, but swapped to a 0.25mm nozzle and went away, and got it to work perfectly after only 2 tries.

I'm including the Gcode for my Robo R2 (4 pc and additional tower to provide cooling time), no guarantees it works on another printer but since Simplify3D seemingly had troubles with the tiny size (it made the teeth outer diameter smaller than the base even if they should be identical, was visible in the preview already) the STL was made to compensate for it and may or may not work as is with another slicer. Source file can be provided if you have trouble and have the appropriate software.

Next step is the styluses... if anyone has good tips for refilling the stock ones or some replacement solutions it's very welcome.

title: E3D titan inductive sensor and endstop mount

description.text:
This is a little bracket I made to mount my inductive sensor and cabling to an original E3D titan extruder on my Wanhao duplicator i3. I did have to remove the drag chain and put my wires in cable organizer wrapping (available at any electronics store).

EDIT: There are 2 versions now. One that uses nuts to secure the sensor and one that uses a M3 set screw.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

If you ever plan on printing ABS it would be wise to print this in PETG or ABS.

Mounting the bracket

I used some of the extra screws that came with the extruder to mount the bracket. If you don't have extras you might need to buy a couple of longer screws. The bracket screws in directly against the extruder's plastic lid using the lid's mounting holes.

The endstop switch screws directly into the plastic bracket using M2 screws. On the Wanhao it is positioned in such a way that the switch touches the stepper when homing.

These designs are worker and drone foundation for a queen rearing nucleus. The worker foundation is 5mm and the drone 7mm. Sheets of foundation (no frame) are provided which could be copied and pasted together for other frame sizes. Three frame designs for wax foundation are provided. One is a four piece push together frame which requires wax foundation to be cut to size. The other two are half frames (print two for complete frame) that require wax foundation to be squeezed between the two halfs. One of the squeeze together fames has small clips to hold the parts together the other relies on the wax to keep the parts together.

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3 Extended

So, I tried to find a Catan card holder that I liked, and was unable to do so. Instead, I decided to make my own. This is my first ever printable object, and although I am happy with it I am sad to report that there is a small error somewhere in the file that prints an easily removable piece of garbage material. Perhaps someone with more experience can fix this? In any case, it works splendidly, and if you print two you will have enough to hold the cards for Cities and Knights as well! To finish it off I stuck little foam rubber bumpers on the bottom to act as feet. Enjoy! Edit: I have posted the original model files as well, with the hopes that someone can successfully merge the original single line card holder into the double line holder that I tried to make. UPDATED 3/1/2014
Thanks to HunterGreen here on Thingiverse I have some revised copies now available. I have no 3d printer at the moment, so I can't test them myself. Because of that I am leaving the original files up until I can see that the new ones are better when printed. The new files are named CatanSkew3. Thanks again Huntergreen!
I printed mine out in ABS and it worked very well. Next batch I am going to print in PLA.

• note - I designed these in inches. If you're working in mm, it might upload the files as teenytiny 3.5mm shapes. Resize the scale to inches, or resize so that the inside area of the sleeves of the hubs will fit the true size of a 1x2 - which is 3/4 inch x 1.5 inch.

INSTRUCTIONS FOR CHEAPEST, EASIEST DOME:
size: approx 14ft wide, 7ft tall, 140sq feet

Print the following:

10 Hexa hubs
6 Penta hubs
5 BBAB hubs
5 BABB hubs

8ft long 1x2 furring strips are what I used. They need to be mostly straight, no cracks.
Link: http://www.homedepot.com/p/1-in-x-2-in-x-8-ft-Furring-Strip-Board-160954/100009348

Cut the wood to 4ft 3in. Those are your "B" struts.
the left over cuts, 3ft 9in, are the "A" Struts.

Assemble according to the diagram using small wood screws. I just took a hub with me into the hardware store and picked one that fit nicely and wasn't super long.

Hexa hubs are marked with A and B sides.
Penta hubs are all "A" sided, so are not marked.
BBAB & BABB pieces are the foundation pieces - thats what you lay out first when you're putting it together.

When laying out the bottom row, foundation pieces, alternate between BBAB and BABB pieces for the correct layout. Look at the assembly diagram closely and it will make sense.

If you want to make a certain sized dome, use this AWESOME calculator to figure out what size your struts need to be, and how much cover material you'll need!

http://www.domerama.com/calculators/2v-geodesic-dome-calculator/

PLEASE POST PICTURES!
GIVE DOMES TO FRIENDS!
MAKE HOMELESS SHELTERS!
MAKE GREEN HOUSES!

YAY LOVE!

If you want to print and sell these, please contact me [email protected] to join my 3D printing Co-Op. I will release a special licence to you that will allow you to sell two dome kits for every one kit you provide to the community for its benefit. We will be stock piling these to provide shelter for people in times of disaster or misfortune,

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nFuhDd6mRw4&feature=youtu.be

description.text:
This pot is self watering, and is the right size for one of those compressed dirt pucks.  
There is a 15x15mm plate on one side to glue it to a mount of some sort in the future.

Print solidly, I would recommend extruding a bit too much plastic just to make sure it is waterproof.   
It should be able to fit a compressed dirt puck used in plant starters. If it doesn't fit, try expanding the puck with water, or scale the model up a little.

description.text:
Simple enclosure for my Brenda 3d printer.
Should work for other printers as well.

printed parts:
-drillhelp, the hole is a bit closer to the edge (2.5mm) so the round edge of the extrusions stays visible.
-door parts
-lcd holder (doesn't fit perfectly but was good enough for me).
-IEC holder
-the atxboard is you use the board from https://www.staticboards.es/productos/atxboard/
I would advise to use different crimps as the provided solution is a bit high, I used a seasonic sfx 350 watt psu.

things to buy:
-polycarbonate, I found mine pre-cut at a good price here:
https://kunststofplatenshop.be/polycarbonaat-platen/helder/
I used 5mm but if I would have to do it again I would maybe try with less (the doors should be 5), 5mm is ok but the weight is a bit much.
If you want to know all measurements (only usefull when you build the same Brenda printer) let me know.

-extrusions and a couple of squares and a lot of nuts (stainless).
http://www.motedis.com/shop/Slot-profiles/Profile-20-I-Type-slot-5/Mechanical-Maker-Packs-20x20-I-Type-slot-512-x-1000mm::5013.html
-http://www.motedis.com/shop/Slot-profile-accessories/Accessories-20-I-Typ-Slot-5/Bracket-Alu-elox-20x20::576.html
http://www.motedis.com/shop/Slot-profile-accessories/Accessories-20-I-Typ-Slot-5/T-nut-with-spring-ball-with-guidance-I-Type-slot-5-M5::4226.html
http://www.motedis.com/shop/Slot-profile-accessories/Accessories-20-I-Typ-Slot-5/T-Nut-with-spring-ball-without-guidance-I-Type-slot-5::451.html
http://www.motedis.com/shop/Mechanical-Basics/Hinges/Hinge-aluminium/Exterior-Hinge-single-hinge-half::1347.html
http://www.motedis.com/shop/Mechanical-Basics/Hinges/Hinge-aluminium/Bolt-for-Internal-exterior-Hinge-aluminium::1348.html

screws are from rsonline (stainless):
http://benl.rs-online.com/web/p/socket-screws/1838660

Heaters are also rsonline (15 watt each):
http://benl.rs-online.com/web/p/products/1592049/
http://benl.rs-online.com/web/p/products/0467406/
http://benl.rs-online.com/web/p/products/1217322/

If you want to mount the led strip in tubes like I did, this fits:
http://benl.rs-online.com/web/p/products/2822256/
put a little bit of oil on the led strip if it wont slide in the tube, I used bike oil.

WARNING:
The heaters are 220 volt, make sure to earth to enclosure with alu squares as polycarbonate is not conductive.
should be safe if you use wago or similar.

If you need any help, just let me know, I'll measure some things and take some more pictures
https://youtu.be/7eRQ2vhsQDU

title: Horten Gotha Prototypes 24.1 and 24.13
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Two prototypes that were never built. The idea was a single seat fighter, somewhat smaller than the famous Go-229. The Horten brothers made only preliminary sketches, but the manufacturer wanted to build prototypes to gain government funding. The fight was not resolved at the end of the war.
Unclear which jet engines would be available, there was a twin engine proposal using BMW engines, or a single engine version using the Heinkel engine.
Due to the position of the twin engines, a 4-point undercarriage was considered, with two single wheels in line along the center line, and two "training wheels" at the wing tips.
Again, this never made it off the paper.

Except on your printer!

If you do print either one, please post a photo.
Thank you!

Notes:

Slice off the wings to get two wings and a fuselage. The slice the fuselage between the canopy and the engine recess. Use the cut planes as the base/bottom for printing.

If you can print this to a 30" wingspan using only spiral vase prints, it will fly. The CG should be a little ahead of the thickest part of the wing root camber.

author: Bogomi67

title: Ultimate Stock Anet A8 Extruder Enclosure w/ Fan Mounts,Cooling Duct & Auto Bed Leveling Sensor Mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Enclosure for a stock, direct feed, extruder head for the Anet A8.

Covers the blower and heatsink fans, and has a built in cooling duct.

The Cooling duct is separated into two parts, the base and the cover, to avoid un-reachable supports inside the hollow cavity, possibly affecting airflow.

Has mounting holes and bottom pass-through hole for the
"Practical 6 - 36V Auto Leveling Sensor"
(http://www.gearbest.com/3d-printer-parts/pp_591321.html)

Has an easy-access mount for the heatsink fan to quickly slip out the fan and heatsink together, to see what's happening in the extruder.

Work in progress, the top piece and back side are still in the works. Made the current parts future-proof with anticipated mounting holes for the other sides.

LOL Kind of don't know how these will print, as I just got bored waiting for my A8 to arrive, and threw something together. I used the parts I remixed for ques for spacing the parts out, so let me know if anything is off so far. I tried to make it as support-less as I could.

Update: 10/26/2017
I've overhauled the entire enclosure, rounded all the edges and have obsoleted certain features or variants.
I've also switched the cooling nozzle design to embed LittleMrJ's i3 DiggityDank Carriage Nozzle.
Top piece completed and connection mechanisms overhauled.
V1 of the enclosure is no longer included, due to how horrible it was LOL
sorry about that.

Update
Made Top Holes into one large hole, to allow for the extruder feeder more clearance

description.text:
The mounting hooks are designed for the Full Graphic Smart Controller case at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:213852

I remade this after seeing this post https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:626446. I really liked this design but the space between the legs was too small for my printer. That's why I redesigned the mounting hooks and made them easier to print and use.

I printed this with a prusa i3. Nuzzle diameter is 0,35mm in PLA. I sliced this with Slic3r with layer height 0,2mm, infill 30% honeycomb, brim 3mm and a average print speed of 50mm/s at a temperature of 180°.

The hooks width is 15mm and has a thickness of 4mm. The space between the legs is 6,5 mm. At the bottom of each leg there is a hole of 3mm. This way you can screw both legs together with a M3 bolt. I designed this with Autodesk Inventor and added the design file so you guys can edit.

I know there are many other versions of this project out there, but I thought I'd still share mine. I used a Ziploc 60 qt. Weathershield box. I printed the two supports for the inside and outside of each side of the box. I used #6 - 32 x 3/4 inch machine screws. I also have a mini-dehumidifier in it to absorb moisture. The supports will fit a piece of 1-inch schedule 40 PVC pipe. I modeled it based on the that diameter and the PVC will snap in place.

I had the screws and PVC laying around, but you can pick those up at any hardware store. The box I bought at Walmart for $13. Amazon carries them too, but at almost twice the price.

I created this to act as a photo prop for my son's second birthday photoshoot

Take a look at the video here : https://youtu.be/SQgF20EjZyU

The stars were printed with Fillamentum PLA Extrafill Rapunzel Silver

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

Process 1 = 5%, Process 2, a couple of mm below the top surface = 20%

Notes:

I used 2 separate processes in Simplify 3D to allow me to keep most of the infill low (5%) bit still reduce the number of top layers (down to 4) and in doing so saved around 6 hrs over my normal settings.

100% scale was design to fit on the CR-10 bed so the height is around 290mm.

Note that if you scale this down that you will need to pay attention to the size of the stars as, for example, 50% scale would also half the tolerance between the star shaped hole and star itself.
Also Note that I made the bottom star cutout a little close to the edge so make sure you take care not to snap the print at this weak point when removing it from the build plate.
Cupholder for PlaySeat gearholder

description.text:
I wanted a way to store playing cards that wasn't the cardboard boxes from the store. So, I made these and they are working great.

There are generally two basic sizes of playing cards. One is called "Bridge" or "narrow" and is 2.25" x 3.5". The other is called "Poker" or "wide" and is 2.5" x 3.5". Most poker rooms in USA use Bridge sized cards to play poker. So, I don't know how the names got mixed up.

Different players prefer different sizes so I made boxes for both.

I also make one or two deck cases. Poker players generally have a "setup" of two decks with different color backs which is my general usage. However, you may want a box for just a single deck so I made those as well.

These fit the KEM, Copaq, DaVinci and other well known all-plastic playing cards. They will also fit most paper cards.

The boxes also stack with the cards flat and have ridges to help keep them in place. They only stack with the same size decks. That is Bridge won't (necessarily) stack on Poker, etc. One deck and Two deck boxes of the same size will stack.

The latch is intended to just help keep the box shut with normal handling. It won't keep the lid on if you attempt to shake it open by the bottom with the lid pointing down. If you need that level of security you could throw a tight rubber band around the box top-to-bottom to keep the lid on securely.

I printed the boxes in the photos with PETG in semi-transparent red or blue. I really like the look of those. I have also printed them in PLA. In both cases I used a 0.4mm nozzle at 0.2mm layer height and 100% infill as the walls are not very thick.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 extruder, 0.2 layers

Infill:

100%

Notes:

PETG works well and looks great. PLA also works well with a slightly tighter fit.

You will want to print a top and bottom of the same size (Bridge or Poker) and deck count (one or two).
I designed this in Fusion 360 using parameters so I just needed to change the deck width to go from Bridge to Poker size and back.
Linhof lens board 77mm for barrel lens.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the "glass" parts separately and use superglue to attach them to the model

description.text:
Welcome to the Galactic British Empire. https://jugglingwithjelly.wordpress.com/galactic-british-empire/

The Brunel Class Starship is the Galactic British Navy's replacement for the aging Trevithick class, now in use throughout the empire it offers a bigger cargo and passenger capacity and improved technology over its predecessor.

This Starship is part of the Galactic British Empire playset.

Starship Body printed in Fillamentum PLA Extrafill Gold Happens
Windows printed in Fillamentum Crystal Clear PLA Iceland Blue

https://fillamentum.com/

NOTE If you do print the "glass" parts then common sense should be applied, they could be a choking hazard for small children if they become detached

Many thanks to Tom for the encouragement, my family for putting up with me constantly printing and Fillamentum for helping me out with their great product encouragement.

More here : https://youtu.be/0h9fTvYl3MA

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

5%

Notes:

This model can be printed with low to no infill and the only sections that really require more are the landing feet. If you have the option of variable settings in your slicer I'd recomend as much as 20% for the feet with a rectilinear pattern, reducing to low or no infill for the majority of the model (honeybomb pattern should be fine. To be totally sure of the point at the top of the model printing well you could up the infill just before that.

I printed the "glass" parts separately and use superglue to attach them to the model

description.text:
A totally redesigned version of my part drawers, a lot less fussy than the previous two versions and very slightly bigger. I've punched holes through the cabinet as an experiment to save on filament (probably doesn't do much with all the additional top and bottom layers!). The drawers are tilted back to stop them sliding out.

4th Sept 2017 Added new version drawers with thinner base, 1.5mm, following feedback by user "Dryphter". Thanks for printing, sharing and feeding back

The Cabinet is 140mm x 83mm x 99mm tall

Cabinet is printed in Fillamentum PLA Extrafill Turquoise Green
Drawers are printed in Fillamentum PLA Extrafill Turquoise Blue

https://fillamentum.com/

No

0.2mm layer height

20%

Obviously you can print any combination if drawers you like

Drawers: 6 hrs @ .2 / 20% infill

Printer/Slicer: Prusa MK2s / standard Slic3r Prusa Edition settings.

Mad props go to ZekTheMad for the original for this - been on my list for ages to print, but I see in the comments Sleeved cards do not fit.. Must have taken many hours to design this so dont forget to credit and give comment of how good this is to ZekTheMad!

Personally to set the game up faster I am going to incorporate in the 4 x trays that fit in the small box (that ZekTheMad also designed!) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:989153 just so its one more thing to make it easier to setup.

TBC, The Boring Company

Whatever Elon Musk names this "hobby", I don't really care. If you need me to explain the context for this, you really need to start following Elon Musk more closely.... That being said, here the context is:
Elon Musk was stuck in LA traffic one day, and thought "You know what could alleviate congestion? Tunnels!" From here, he purchased a tunnel boring machine, named it Godot after the play "Waiting for Godot", and also went to a pet store and purchased a snail, which he named Gary. The purpose was to show that Gary, a notoriously slow snail, is currently still faster than the machines we bore tunnels with. The eventual goal of TBC appears to be to dig hyperloops throughout the united states, starting with LAX-SFO and BWI-JFK, but no one is sure what Musk is thinking until he does it.

This has improved my water flow so much. The water in the pool just circles around and around now. I use this with a 2100 GPH pump on a 15x48 Intex Ultra pool.

This one is longer than the original and when slicing I lowered it to remove the bottom lip. You can print it with or without the lip. It's held in by friction and I can easily turn it to point where I'd like. I point it more downward when I have my solar pool cover on it. I point it slightly below horizontal when the cover is off and I can point it upward when I need to cool the pool water off. Works great!

description.text: The is a foldable 20mm cube. The print is a concept for making larger structures with very fast prints, but still achieving excellent surface quality. This print is also useful for learning how to glue or bind the seams.
Print fold and glue. I used hot glue, but other adhesives should work. It's a quick print so experiment with your first one and use what you learn on the second.

created layout of faces
extruded to 1.2mm height
45 degree chamfer on all edges
extruded to 0.1mm height and merged with chamfered model

the second extrude ensures the base layer is a single layer in the slicer. This is important to keep edges from breaking along print line seams.

print_settings.Notes:: Parts with no designator just need to be printed once. All parts are at the optimal orientation for part strength in assembly and play and/or detail, which may conflict in some cases with bed adhesion (which is why I used brims).

description.text:
This is my first major project to teach myself how to use TinkerCAD to draft and create my own designs. Perhaps a transformer is ambitious, but I had to have a good challenge.

Azimuth, according to the transformers wiki, was an original member of the Patterner movement, along with Perceptor (which is why he is pictured here with her for size comparison). Azimuth, after a series of fanfic events I wrote, lost her vehicle form in exchange for the ability to become a Spacebridge. She acts as the herald and defender of the titan Astrologia, one of the as-yet-unnamed 13 original titans that left Cybertron to settle the universe. Azimuth's titan master partner, Acies, allows her to manipulate and shape raw energon, like the omnicons in Transformers: Energon.

(Acies is not part of this project; she was constucted by replacing the face on a mostly-color-coordinated titan master with this face from Shapeways: https://www.shapeways.com/product/F4GCXENJN/slipstream-earth-war-titans-return?optionId=61983229 )

As you can see from the .stl for the back and the one teaser image, Azimuth is just a part of a massive overall project that I am working on. Stay tuned for that project!

Azimuth is compatible with the current Titan's Return titan master figures, and the upcoming Power of the Primes prime master figures (she can hold two of the master-style figures in robot mode and one in her alt-modes). She is also compatible with the full armory from Skyblast in Transformers: Energon and the full armory of Signal Flare from Transformers: Energon with the optional adapter included in the files.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.05mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

I used a lot of brim material on some of these pieces, because nothing irks me worse than failed prints, and I used supports on anything over 55 degrees with 25% infill on supports to get the nice rounded ball joints with less work.

Parts marked with the -R- designator need to have a reversed copy printed as well. All these parts are the right side (I believe; checked the best I could).

Parts marked with the -D- designator need to be printed in duplicate for both sides.

Parts with no designator just need to be printed once. All parts are at the optimal orientation for part strength in assembly and play and/or detail, which may conflict in some cases with bed adhesion (which is why I used brims).

Assembly

Most of the parts with ball-and-socket joints just fit together with a little force. Don't worry about pushing too hard with your fingers The lumbar hinge is a super tight fit into the back (required using the heel of my hand the ridge of a table, and a bit of force), but turns nice and smooth once it is in place. The chest and lumbar hinges are just PLA filament in the same color as the waist sections, soldered flat against the sides of the waist. The same goes for the hands: use filament in the same color as the forearms. The shoulders are also the same, using filament the same color as the chest. The same soldering treatment is applied to the ankle pins once they are pushed through the legs, so printing them in the same color as the legs is a good idea.

Painting

I used standard, cheap acrylic paints with a clear acrylic spray overcoat on everything but the titan master's face (turns out that material is choice for absorbing paint). I also took a page from toy restoration sites and used clear nail polish to tighten up joints that get loose over time (or start that way, in the case of the feet).

This was designed exclusively in TinkerCAD. I went through quite a few iterations of the torso bit, settling on the option that was both the most solid and required the fewest pieces to get the desired result.

description.text: I made an adjustable mount with 5 degrees increments for the Xiamoi Yi mounted on a Lisam 210 frame. I´m sure it could be used for other action cameras as well. Enjoy :)

This is a model for foamcore to organise and facilitate quick set-up and pack-up. It could be adapted to a wooden material by reducing the thickness of the material (or using a 5mm material).

The top tray sits above the bottom tray. There is a separate tray for all the player pieces plus starting player, and a separate tray for gold. Player and game boards as well as manual can sit above or below.

The top tray is a resources tray, and contains all the resources used in the game excluding food (which is put in a separate tray that is not included in the model but sits above the cards space on bottom tray, and gold. It is intended to sit on the desk.

Can be made from a single 20" x 30" (508mm x 762mm) sheet of foamcore with plenty left over.

The resources can be arranged in the top tray in a few different ways, but grain fits best in the largest compartment.
This is a cover set I made for a floor bolt. It makes it easier for people to use and prevents the sharp edges from tearing up your shoes.

title: Meade ETX-60 Solar Filter 62 mm Adapter

description.text:
At the last minute I decided to get a solar filter for my Meade ETX-60. I devised a lens cover and then modified it with an ISO threaded 0.75 pitch 62 mm hole (which printed best at 63.4 mm, so with shrinkage the filter had sufficient purchase to dig in and stay), see photo.

The filter was a bargain on ebay. It has good qualities for a low price glass adjustable density 0-400 filter. Search ebay on ZOMEI 52/55/58/62/67/72/77/82mm Adjustable Neutral Density Fader filter ND2-400 or search for the supplier 2014bingozomei. Purist photographers hate adjustable filters for artifacts the polarizers introduce in the details. Here's a positive review of the zomei at the end of this bulletin board post: https://www.canonrumors.com/forum/index.php?topic=28801.0

The files included here are the ETX-60 filter adapter (it's my lens cap with a hole punched in it) and a test disk to try out the hole without printing a complete lens cap (make sure it is cold before releasing from table or it will warp and not work-it's 3 mm thick) and finally the ISO hole if you want to punch a hole in your own lens cap design to adapt a filter. IGNORE that the test disk is in the thumbnail above with the adapter cap, the file is only the cap, the test disk is a separate file

WARNING WILL ROBINSON WARNING WARNING! The screw and the test disk are UPSIDE DOWN in the files above. When you adapt these file to your own end cap design make sure you FLIP THEM 180 DEGREES. If you forget you will have a big surprise with the threads going the wrong way. WARNING WARNING WARNING. The solar filter cap is threaded correctly and the file prints correctly because the thread must start on the heated surface not as oriented in the parts above, that's why you fiip it, the orientation of the threads to how the adapter is being printed. The fit is snug on the ETX-60, like an end cap.

description.text: A little guide for the filament on the top of the Rostock Max. I didn't like that the filament was scraping on the laser cut melamine and leaving powder behind, so I whipped up this quick guide and printed it in nice slippery Nylon 618. Build in OpenSCAD so you can customize the tolerance etc.
Print slowly in Nylon, best printed 2 at a time or more. Your printer may vary, but I had to drill the hole out just a bit to get it to a true 2mm even with the tolerance I have built in.

title: Solar Filter Holder - Canon 58mm lens with 2 tabs

description.text:
This solar filter film holder fits a Canon EF 58mm lens. I found that the existing versions on Thingiverse had three locking tabs, where my lenses require just two. Plus, I was not satisfied with the wrinkles that other holders introduced in the film. Is easily removed for normal exposure during full totality.

Print as shown. Designed to print without supports and to press fit the film using the top into the body cavity. Cut the film to the size of the top to fit. Most printers will print the top to get a reasonable friction fit into the body. If it's not a tight enough, tape in the corners works just fine.

HungryHam added to this with an excellent cover for the filter holder. It worked great for me during the eclipse. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2486426/#comments.

title: Anycubic i3 Mega Filament Sensor Filament Insertion Guide

description.text:
I found it to be a pain in the patootie to get the filament to slide into the filament sensor and out the other side. Usually had to pull it off and fuss with it. So I made this little do-dad that inserts into the open slot to give the filament a nice straight path up to the roller. Since the hole for the filament is only 3mm I recommend printing this at .1mm, 100% infill, highest quality setting.

I also made a couple different attachments to route the filament into the guide depending on where your spool is. I like the funnel best.

The photo shows the filament being fed from behind but that's because I turned the printer to take the photo. I normally have the spool on a shelf to the right of the printer. It feeds great from both locations. There is a bit of added resistance but I don't see any problems with my prints so far.

This is made to go with the filament sensor holder I made:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2443027

title: Igus E-Chain Links with Bendable Cable Clips

description.text:
igus E-Chain original links and one I edited (has 'T' watermark) for print. I took .02mm off the pins (.04 total) and .02 off the inner faces. Hoping to get some feedback on print-in-place links and get this perfected.
I appreciate the fair play of igus with their CAD files. With this approach to fair use, a lot more ideas can be prototyped and tested faster with duplicated parts.
I have used the igus E-Chain earlier on my ShopBot. This incredible plastic material behaves like high grade aluminum in many ways.
http://www.igus-cad.com/prevpggroup.aspx?wer=6

Editable here at Orchard:
https://3dorchard.com/app/single/58ba2ea8c5c1b30ce4ce4c0f/59923f9da64458096c3f022f
We had a discussion in the Engineering group regarding the term used for something that functions right off the build plate. Seems that 'print-in-place' is the term so far, but I like 'functionable' because it describes this result better.

author: zackboston

description.text:
2020 Filament guide for the universal spool bearing.
If you need to twist the filament guide in order to make it better , you can use a heat gun to soften the plastic then twist to costum

A popping polyhedron powered by rubber bands. Folds flat and pops into its 3D form when released. It's fully parametric and includes filament hinges that can be used in other projects. You can see a seven second movie of it here: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/1775688/popbox.m4v If you want to use the hinges in another project, go see my Hinge Variations http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:266956.

Makes a Pop Box: a six faced object with rubber bands inside that can be flattened to a half-hexagon shape and will pop-back into a three-dimensional shape. As well as the print, you'll need two small rubber-bands. The hinge pins are filament.

  • Before printing all six faces, pick out some 1.8mm diameter filament for use as the hinge pins and print just one face.

  • Check that the inside diameter of the hinge with the three parts is a tightish fit for the filament. It should be tight enough to grip it, but not so tight that you can't get it in. The inside diameter of the hinges with two parts is slightly larger to allow that hinge to rotate freely. A simple fix for filament that is too large is to slim it a little with sandpaper and shape the end into a point so it more easily slips through the hinge holes.

  • Once you have found suitable filament, or adjusted the inside diameter appropriately, print all six faces. As provided the faces are 1.4mm thick and 50mm on a side. The hinges are 5mm diameter. You can go with a thickness as low as 1mm and drop the hinge size to 4mm. If you make large faces, increase the number of hinge sections, keeping it as an odd number. Compile popbox.scad in OpenSCAD and export as STL. You'll need the other two SCAD files in the same folder as popbox.scad. I've successfully printed a number of these in PLA at 0.2mm layer height.

  • Assemble the top three faces in the row, inserting filament in the hinges and cutting it flush.

  • Assemble the bottom three faces in the row, again inserting filament and cutting it flush.

  • Assemble the top three and bottom three together at the middle triangle, but leave about 4mm of filament sticking out at both ends. These will anchor the rubber bands.

  • Assemble both ends, this time leaving 4mm filament sticking out at the open end of the Pop Box only. These two ends will anchor the other ends of the rubber bands.

  • Push a rubber band in through the slot in the back and anchor it at one end. You will need to force it between the filament and the triangle face. Open the Pop Box part way and pull the rubber band diagonally across and hook it onto the filament sticking out of the opposite side. Force it down between the filament and the face.

  • Repeat for the other rubber band. The two rubber bands should cross in the center and will just fit between the two half-height hinges when the Pop Box is flat.

description.text:
This is a replacement part for the latches used on fluorescent vaporproof / vaportight fixtures. The swim club that I belong to uses these fixtures in the locker rooms, and this is the part which seems to break most readily. Replacement latches are available at Amazon, but they are $3 each - not too expensive, but I do have a 3D printer...

Your mileage may vary with these - they work fine on our lights.

No suitability for purpose is expressed or implied. These seem to work fine, but the actual use is your responsibility.

Search for LCW Vaporproof/Vaportight plastic clips on Amazon to find production replacement parts.

Printer:

Monoprice Delta Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25% or greater

Notes:

I made these out of PLA, and they seem plenty strong at 25% infill. Time will tell on their durability, but you can always make more.

For the ultimate fix, feel free to mill one from billet Aluminum. Just be ready to find out that the other parts are now the weak link.
Designed in Fusion 360, based on measurements from a broken part.

This is based on the work done by some of the people on this thread:

  • https://forum.xcsoar.org/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=1551&start=50

They discovered that sunlight was causing the IR touch detection on the Kobo Mini to lock up when used in a glider. This simple light shield does not block the edge of the screen and serves to physically protect the screen. It seems to improve touch detection somewhat even when the Kobo Mini is used in normal lighting. The inner curve is intended to throw any reflections out of focus (PETG was used to insure the shield would sit flat and it is shiny). The colour used for the material was, of course, black. I used silicone RTV to glue it to the Kobo Mini as I happen to know that it will peel off if required.

This light shield has been used for a fair number of flights and the lockup problem has not reoccurred.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2809260 ]

Here is my design for a more reliable filament runout sensor, designed for mounting on and below a 2020 bar. I'm using it on a Folgertech FT-5, with the filament spool above it, but it should be usable with other printers with similar bars for mounting.

Background
I've been trying to install a reliable sensor for some time (tried like about six different designs including several variations of some of those!) but always seemed to run into problems. My issues might be from the type of printing I've been doing -- large objects printed with a wide nozzle so that filament gets used quickly (which is why there is urgent need for a sensor!) and the filament usually moves through the system quickly causing vibration and significant tension changes.

Sensors that depend on filament directly pushing a microswitch closed, while seemingly simple, turned out to be a balancing act between having the switch tight enough against the filament that it causes a drag on the extruder and shuttle, or the switch causing too many false alarms to be of much use. They're also a pain to feed filament through.

Basic optical based sensors failed because the opto-interrupters they depend on use IR light, which many filament types -- and seemingly all PETG ones -- are transparent to. The alignment of the beam in the interruptor is also very critical when it needs to be blocked with skinny 1.75mm wide filament, so false alarms were still a problem even when printing with just black PLA.

Other runout sensor types included motion sensing (the range of motion to be handled varies a lot from using a 1mm nozzle or with a 0.2mm nozzle) and spool weight sensing (vibration results in unacceptably poor accuracy).

So, anyway, how does this new one work?
It uses an optical sensor, but the sensor isn't triggered directly by the filament but instead by a flag that breaks the beam. When the filament runs out it causes a lever to drop which makes a flag fall into the beam . The lever is otherwise held up by filament that runs between two in-line pieces of PTFE tubing; the filament can't bend sharply enough to allow the flag low enough to break the beam. The teflon tubing causes very little drag on the filament flow and the sensor state is immune to vibration or erratic movement of the filament. See illustration.

The assembly uses just three printed parts and: a 608 bearing (of fidget-spinner fame); quantity 3 of M3x30 (or #4x1.25") screws and nuts; two PC4-M10 Bowden tube connectors; about a half meter of 4mmOD PTFE tube; and a standard cheap optical end-stop board. The assembly mounts to the 2020 bar using the usual screws and T-Nuts (M4 or M5, one or two).

IMPORTANT
This design uses an optical IR interrupter sensor, so it can not directly "see" the flag if that part is made with some types of filament. I used blue PETG for mine and put a small piece of black heat-shrink tubing over the little flag to make it opaque to IR light. A small piece of black duct tape also works. Things that DON'T work: black magic marker; masking tape; electrical tape. Black paper taped on will probably work, as will just printing from most solid dark PLA or ABS filament. You can tell if the flag is blocking IR as the red indicator LED on the opto sensor board will go out completely when the beam is successfully blocked.

Be careful, the printed flag is thin and fragile and easy to break (or to melt if you are using heat-shrink tubing). Go carefully if you need to attach an opaque cover to the little flag, and make sure that the flag can still easily fall into the gap in the opto-interruptor! The mounting holes for the opto board are slightly oversized to allow you to fine-adjust the flag to fit within its gap.

Note that operation of nearly any type of runout sensor depends on the filament freely leaving its spool when it runs out. Don't use filament brands that tape the end to the unreachable inside part of the spool (!) and make sure to clip off any bit of filament that may snag the spool at the end (you can usually reach the inside end of the filament through the hole in the center of the spool).

Notes:
Push the 608 bearing all the way into the provided opening in the lever arm, until it seats inside the opening -- the bearing should end about flush with the end of the opening. Using a vice is an easy way to accomplish this if you can't do it by hand.

Arrange the PC4-M10 connectors so that the plastic push-cap faces away from the spool on the line of filament travel, so the print head can't pull the PTFE tube out of position. The PC4-M10 type connectors were used because 4mm PTFE tube can be pushed all the way through them if fed from the push-cap end. Make sure to put a short section of PTFE tube in the connector on the "lever arm" piece before assembling the lever arm onto the mount, because you wont be able to get it to go through feeding it from the metal end of the connector.

The PC4-M10 that screws into the "mount" piece could have only a short piece of PTFE tube in it if you want to use it like a filament guide (with loose filament going from there to the extruder). But -- it is much better to run a longer PTFE tube from the "mount" to the extruder (this is called a "Reverse Bowden" arrangement). That way, the length of filament between the extruder and the mount (and spool) is always constant, flow of filament from spool to extruder runs more smoothly, and any tendencies for filament to spill over the edges of the spool will go away. A better way, overall! The extra weight from a longer PTFE tube is really negligible.

Wiring: the cable and connectors provided with the opto endstop boards probably aren't long enough to reach to the controller board, so you'll have to extend them (using any gauge wire available). A wiring diagram for an MKS gen 1.4 board is shown in the illustrations. Code modifications for Marlin are provided in an attached file.

Opto end-stop boards: https://www.amazon.com/BIQU-Optical-Endstop-Control-Printer/dp/B01FLSA47O/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1502728465&sr=8-2&keywords=optical+limit+switch

comments.text: Props for the design but the best and only way to design this is using a positional encoder. That will detect when the filament stops moving for a period of time like it does during a jam.  I set mine to 20-30 seconds.  Tunnell filament monitor is unfortunately only for Flashforge/Repicator with Sailfish.  I was hugely dissapointed to see there is no equivalent for RepRap when I got my original Prusa i3 MK2S.
comments.author: ChuckNorr15

comments.text: Well, ok.  But after 20 to 30 seconds of a filament jam, the print is pretty much ruined, so not a lot really gained except that you get to start over sooner.  Better to attack the filament jam problem itself (a direct drive with a reverse Bowden has been working well for the for me since I went that way, filament never hops off the spool now).   Jams aren't the problem being attacked here, I'm targeting filament running out without having to babysit the printer.  This one pauses the print immediately when the filament runs out -- before things get messed up, not 20 to 30 seconds afterward.
comments.author: ChuckNorr15

comments.text: If you are printing with ABS you cant resume anyways after the part cools there will be no layer adhesion.  If resuming a print for PLA is your concern set the sensor to 4 seconds.  You can resume just fine missing a bit of filament in one layer.  Ive done it with success with Nylon and PLA.
comments.author: bwaslo

comments.text: Sounds as if your filament path jams a lot, I'd fix that before going with a motion sensor.

description.text:
So a friend is doing a series of Star Trek related geocaches and asked me to make one. This is the result. Although it took about forever to get it printed. I am using ABS and had really severe warping issues. I ended up buy printing both of the larger items with a substantial brim in order to get it to stick. The cube was the worst as it has very little surface (10mm) touching the bed. It failed around 6-7 times. It failed the most when using a raft, and even using a brim I had to enclose the printer in my case with a large cardboard box.

To use the box as a geocache you will need 10mm x 2mm round magnets like this https://goo.gl/jby2LB
You will also want to use either rite in the rain paper or another container, bison or dna tube or a film canister, inside as it it is not water tight

Print 8 of the retainers as there are 4 spots on the lid and the box for magnets.

thanks to Simakrima for the great design. that was easy to print!

in case you want to tinker with it here are the tinkercad links
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1h7a7ijdAmZ-copy-of-borg-cube-bottom
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1DvOzJOUNps-copy-of-borg-cube

description.text:
There's been a slight modification of the dimensions to make the mount work better as well as the addition of a tripod that snaps together and can be positioned the way you like before gluing, or you can just leave it with the joints unglued.

This is a sci fi slug thrower collection that can be used in 15mm and larger scales. This is sort of like a sci fi version of the old dependable Ma Deuce, sending lots of hot lead (or whatever they fire in the future) downrange. I made a shield that should hold tight to the regular and heavy slug throwers. There's also a light portable version that should work great for 25mm or larger scale.

The model consists of the weapon, ammo box, small cartridge belt, a variety of mounts and a tripod. The mounts allow you to attach this slug thrower to walls or other objects with thicknesses of 2mm, 3mm, 4mm, 5mm and 6mm. You can make your own mount by simply adding a 3mm diameter by 3mm tall post. You may need to file or cut the pieces to make them fit perfectly due to the small sizes. I played with extrusion rates and temp until I got it just right but you may still need to cut away that tiny lip you get on the first layer.

The tripod scale is a little large and might work good up to 28mm as is.

Don't glue the mounts in if you want to be able to traverse your fire.

Sorry about my terrible pant job - I'm just a beginner at painting.

In the pictures, the slug thrower is mounted to dutchmogul's Battle Lines
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2093294

new shot glass i invented for the makerbot giveaway

Domo with seperate arms you glue
in the position you choose modeled in sculptris and truespace 5
i made the body , legs and eyes in sculptris.
the teeth, and arms I made in truespace 5.
I also used truespace to "drill" the conical arm sockets in the body, and to make the feet have flat bottoms. pic of glued and permanent marker "painted" Domo shows him in his best form 8 of these magnets on his feet (i use "crazy glue" to position the magnets, and then encapsulate the
magnets in epoxy) makes Domo on my
car hoood stay put at highway speeds!
http://www.harborfreight.com/10-piece-rare-earth-magnets-67488.html
(and No i don't own stock in Harbor freight!)

I printed with support on, it only puts a small support on the underside
which was really easy to clean up The arms have a ball shaped shoulder that you glue into the conical
holes in the body.
This gives a wide range of angles you can glue the arms into. I printed this pretty big, but I am fairly sure even a much smaller print
would yield reasonable detail.

So... I really like the design of Makerbot's new extruder, and I wanted to try it out.  My solution? Since I already have a Printrbot, I decided to design an adapter to mount it with.  
Edit: My printrbot seems to not accept the M92 command from pronterface.  This means that I cannot recalibrate my e-steps, and my printer cant use this new extruder.  Anyone who can help with this, I would appreciate it.

comments.text:
I actually fixed the problem with the steps/mm being wrong a while ago.... Turns out that the Printrbot is weird, and instead of being able to change the gcode settings on the board, you need to add the M92 command into the starting gcode in your slicer program.
Also, the correct steps/mm is 88.95 in case anyone else out there has had trouble implementing this.

description.text:
--- Description ---
This a weighted poker card capper of a topographical map of Montana. It is placed on your hole cards during a hand to make sure they are not accidentally folded.

If you like this you may want to checkout my collection of card cappers

--- Printing ---
1) Print the top at 70%
2) Print the base at 100%

--- Assembly ---
1) The base is designed to have 4 nickels placed inside of it as ballast prior to assembly.
2) Super glue the base to the top to trap the ballast inside.

Enjoy and if you print one please post a picture!

title: Finger Saver
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I made this to fit over the props of my Quadrysteria Rush 4" racing quad. Every time I pick it up with the battery plugged in I feel like I am picking up a human blender. This contraption will capture the props, should they start to spin.

I have not printed this yet. I am throwing it out there as a concept design. Hopefully it will save some fingers. Future edits might include removing angles > 45 degrees to eliminate the need for supports in the few areas that could currently benefit from them.

**Note: The Rush is not a symmetrical frame. The back motors are closer together than the front motors. It is likely that you will have to edit the pod spacing to fit your application. I made it for 4x4.5 bullnose racing props.

This vase is fairly large and printed in 79 hours 52 minutes. I used a layer height of 0.200 mm and a print speed of 100 mm/sec.

Because this part is another double twist design means it results in ovelapping shells that can cause problems for slicing programs. The subject of overlapping shells is complex and this blog page can give you information about this: http://birkbinnard.com/blog/do-the-twist/. Because of these issues (which are actually issues with the structure of STL files) I had to use the Prusa version of Slic3r to slice this file. Neither Simplify3D 4.0 or Craftware 1.14 would slice it properly.

The vase has 2 colors simply because I mis-judged the amount of filament left on the blue reel and I had to switch to a different one to finish the print.

description.text:
This is my first design - a little box to replace the back of the Pimoroni Pirate Radio: https://shop.pimoroni.com/products/pirate-radio-pi-zero-w-project-kit

It is still far from HiFi, but (in my opinion) the radio sounds at least a bit better with this.

Print:
Print upside down (speaker hole located on the heat bed)

Assembly:

  • Remove the stand, backplates and the speaker
  • Put the nuts into the box's nut holes, fix them with tape (so they don't fall out before tightening the screws)
  • Put the speaker in/on the box with the cable coming out the side hole
  • Mount box & speaker on the radio

Update 2017-08-19: Increased size of screw/nut holes
Update 2017-08-21: Moved nut hole further to the front (otherwise the screws are too short...)

description.text:
This is a enclosure, lid, and mount for a Meanwell EPP-400 3"x5" Small Form Factor PSU. It's currently a work in progress. Currently this is the bottom lid, which has bracings that are spaced for the Ultibots D300VS 2020 extrusions and standoffs for M3 screws.

There will be two lids for this enclosure, one which is fanless and not recommended for actual use with the D300VS as it is only rated for 250w that way.

The intended lid will include a duct for a 70mm blower, that while nearly as large as the PSU itself, only puts out ~22dB for the 33cfm of air it moves.

This model is designed to protect the electronic components of the frame of the quadcopter THOR210 v1.
The weight is about 15 grams.
There is a mounting for a LED WS2812B.

print_settings.Notes:: Print the mold twice in something like PETG or ABS and the main part in PLA. In the photos above, I've printedthe mold in PETG and the dodger in glow in the dark PLA. Using boiling or near-boiling water, a butane torch, a heated bed, or another heat source, bring the dodger main part up to plasticity. Place it between the two interlocking mold pieces and smash a lot. Apply stickers and epoxy resin as desired. If you use it inline and catch a koke post a comment please.

description.text: this is a simple adapter to mount the larger kk2 boards to a 30.5mm hole spacing of many quad frames for the flight controller. you could print this with tpu or other flexible filaments to reduce vibrations.

print_settings.Notes:: Print with high infill. The base piece is meant to be printed flat, then carefully using a butane torch, boiling or off-boiling water, or a very hot hotbed, heat the piece and shape it as per the video. You may attach as many of the bases printed to a smaller ratio inline behind it with the fish pieces printed and places laterally. Attach reflective stickers and/or epoxy resin. Attached video printed at 100% at .2 layer height in Atomic PETG.

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RFDBL0xSe9U

Most salmon fenders are meant to simulate a school of fish by thrashing a big piece of plastic around during trolling. I'm not sure if the fish actually know, but it's unconvincing. This is meant to be a 3-or-more piece fender printable modular and added to as needed. You can hang it off your trolling rig or off your downrigger weight like any other salmon flasher. All the hardware came off a walmart shelf.
